articles.headline: A Start-Up Turns to Saffron to Help Afghanistan Regrow
articles.snippet: Rumi Spice, started by Army veterans, is part of efforts to help develop Afghanistan’s resource economy.
articles.abstract: Rumi Spice, started by Army veterans, is part of efforts to help develop Afghanistan’s resource economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bomb-blasted roads, frequent blackouts, shortages of basic equipment and an untested consumer market are hardly conditions that make for natural entrepreneurial opportunities.

articles.headline: One Ally Remains Firmly Behind Donald Trump: The N.R.A.
articles.snippet: With the nominee increasingly isolated in his own party, the gun rights group has become one of his remaining supporters within the G.O.P. coalition.
articles.abstract: With the nominee increasingly isolated in his own party, the gun rights group has become one of his remaining supporters within the G.O.P. coalition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s candidacy has driven away throngs of Republican elected officials, donors and policy experts. But not the National Rifle Association.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Greek Crisis, the Book. Or Actually Several of Them.
articles.snippet: As the anniversary of Greece’s bailout deal approaches, memoirs and essays about that nation’s economic crisis abound.
articles.abstract: As the anniversary of Greece’s bailout deal approaches, memoirs and essays about that nation’s economic crisis abound.
articles.lead_paragraph: In May last year, James K. Galbraith, a left-leaning American economist, sent an email to Greece’s finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, in which he argued that an exit from the eurozone would benefit Greece.

articles.headline: In Baltimore Report, Justice Dept. Revives Doubts About Zero-Tolerance Policing
articles.snippet: The broken-windows style of policing that New York evangelized is increasingly seen as a source of community tensions, not a successful crime-fighting strategy.
articles.abstract: The broken-windows style of policing that New York evangelized is increasingly seen as a source of community tensions, not a successful crime-fighting strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has criticized a string of police departments nationwide for unfairly targeting blacks, but in its report on the Baltimore police, issued Wednesday, it used its most scathing language to date to denounce the zero-tolerance policing approach that has spread from New York to many departments big and small.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Joseph Goldstein

articles.headline: Harassment Crisis Builds at Fox News, Despite Its Swift Response
articles.snippet: The ouster of Roger Ailes and an internal inquiry have done little to halt a drumbeat of new accusations of misogyny at Fox News.
articles.abstract: The ouster of Roger Ailes and an internal inquiry have done little to halt a drumbeat of new accusations of misogyny at Fox News.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the anchor Gretchen Carlson filed a bombshell lawsuit accusing the Fox News chairman Roger Ailes of sexual harassment, Fox’s corporate masters moved fast.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Emily Steel and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Hack of Democrats’ Accounts Was Wider Than Believed, Officials Say
articles.snippet: A Russian cyberattack is now thought to have breached the private email accounts of more than 100 party officials and groups.
articles.abstract: A Russian cyberattack is now thought to have breached the private email accounts of more than 100 party officials and groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Russian cyberattack that targeted Democratic politicians was bigger than it first appeared and breached the private email accounts of more than 100 party officials and groups, officials with knowledge of the case said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Airbnb and Others Set Terms for Employees to Cash Out
articles.snippet: As Silicon Valley start-ups have delayed initial public offerings or sales, they have come under pressure to let their employees sell some of their private stock.
articles.abstract: As Silicon Valley start-ups have delayed initial public offerings or sales, they have come under pressure to let their employees sell some of their private stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology start-ups have long wrestled with a conundrum of how to reward their employees. Many of their workers are compensated with lucrative piles of a start-up’s stock, but cannot cash it in because the shares do not trade publicly.

articles.headline: Driven to Suicide by an ‘Inhuman and Unnatural’ Pressure to Sell
articles.snippet: Jobs with global powerhouses like Abbott are highly prized positions in India, but they can also put employees under inordinate pressure to cut corners, according to a Times investigation.
articles.abstract: Jobs with global powerhouses like Abbott are highly prized positions in India, but they can also put employees under inordinate pressure to cut corners, according to a Times investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDORE, India — Leaving his wife and two young children home on a recent Sunday, a 27-year-old salesman for Abbott Laboratories’ operations in India — in fact, one of the American health care company’s top performers there — rode his motorcycle to a remote railroad track and jumped in front of a train.
articles.byline: By Geeta Anand and Frederik Joelving

articles.headline: The Millions of Americans Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Barely Mention: The Poor
articles.snippet: While their economic platforms are markedly different, both candidates promise to create jobs but have said little about helping people while they are not working.
articles.abstract: While their economic platforms are markedly different, both candidates promise to create jobs but have said little about helping people while they are not working.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States, the wealthiest nation on Earth, also abides the deepest poverty of any developed nation, but you would not know it by listening to Hillary Clinton or Donald J. Trump, the major parties’ presidential nominees.

articles.headline: Beyond Olympic Glow, a Vicious Drug War Rages in Rio
articles.snippet: In Rio de Janeiro’s sprawling slums, gang fights and police raids provide a stark contrast to the excitement of the Olympic Games happening just across the city.
articles.abstract: In Rio de Janeiro’s sprawling slums, gang fights and police raids provide a stark contrast to the excitement of the Olympic Games happening just across the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Fans were lining up to watch an American beach volleyball duo square off against Mexico on the alluring sands of Copacabana Beach.

articles.headline: In Michigan, Hillary Clinton Calls Donald Trump Enemy of ‘the Little Guy’
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton accused Mr. Trump of feigning support for working Americans, saying his tax proposals would “give trillions in tax breaks to people like himself.”
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton accused Mr. Trump of feigning support for working Americans, saying his tax proposals would “give trillions in tax breaks to people like himself.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — In a full-throttled rejection of Donald J. Trump’s economic policies, Hillary Clinton on Thursday accused him of feigning a connection to the working man, while advocating policies that would “work for him and his friends, at the expense of everyone else.”
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Arianna Huffington Is Leaving Huffington Post
articles.snippet: Ms. Huffington helped begin the media company, now owned by Verizon, in 2005 and will be focusing on her new venture, Thrive Global.
articles.abstract: Ms. Huffington helped begin the media company, now owned by Verizon, in 2005 and will be focusing on her new venture, Thrive Global.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since it started 11 years ago, The Huffington Post has been synonymous with the personality and the interests of its co-founder, Arianna Huffington.

articles.headline: Macy’s to Close 100 Stores as E-Rivals and Discounting Hit Legacy Retailers
articles.snippet: Macy’s announcement closely follows that of Walmart, which said it would buy Jet.com in what is widely viewed as a way to invigorate its online sales.
articles.abstract: Macy’s announcement closely follows that of Walmart, which said it would buy Jet.com in what is widely viewed as a way to invigorate its online sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: The great American consumer is very much alive. It’s just that people aren’t shopping like they used to, reluctant to pay full price or even leave the couch — cutting deep into the business of many top retailers.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Sapna Maheshwari
